Detailed Description

The generated lookup table span across std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::min() and std::numeric_limits<int16_t>::max(), both of them are included in the range.

Whether to use the reverse look up or forward look up is linked to the chosen DepthSense::ROM::CyclicErrorAlgorithmID. The legacy DepthSense::ROM::CYCLIC_ERROR_C2S2C4S4 algorithm will generate a forward lookup table while the DepthSense::ROM::CYCLIC_ERROR_INDIRECT_12_HARMONICS_MODEL will generate the reverse look up table.

Note that if the cyclic error correction is approaching of not being a bijection anymore, reversing the lookup table might introduce large rounding errors. Indeed when the cyclic error correction is approaching of not being a bijection, some large plateaus can appear... which means that multiple output values maps to a unique input value. However the coefficients we normally get after calibration are small enough to ensure that the function is a bijection even when discretized/rounded as int16_t.

int16_t DepthSense::Calc::cyclic_error_correction_lookup_table::operator[] ( int16_t  index)
inline

Note that the lookup value is a signed short as the lookup values spans from SHRT_MIN to SHRT_MAX (included).
